titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. I had been for several days, not altogether well—and rose this morning with an unusual pain in my head, just over my eyes, which felt as if they had been strained by too strong a light.— Yet I walked with Mrs: Adams before breakfast, and afterwards at noon, an hour alone. Upon returning home from this last walk I found myself very much fatigued, with pains all round the loins, and in almost all my limbs. I dined however, but with much less appetite than usual, and soon after dinner, felt so feverish that I laid down on the bed, and slept an hour or two— Lord Talbot and Mr: Harris called to pay us a visit; being here on their way to Vienna, in company with Lord Minto— They proceed on their journey early to-morrow morning.— I rose to see them— But after they were gone, was obliged to go to bed again— I thought I had taken a severe cold and needed a strong perspiration—for which purpose I took a glass of hot wine and water— The Doctor (Ambrozi) happening to call in the Evening, was of opinion from my symptoms that my complaint will prove to be an Ague and fever, which I was very unwilling to believe.

2. Was in a strong perspiration all night, and had no sleep; but find myself better this day. The fever however is not entirely gone, and the Doctor gave me a preparation of salts which though it operated several times in the course of the day, was, I believe too gentle— Count Neale called to visit us this day, being on his return from Carlsbad to Berlin; on account of his Sister, Madame de Zennert’s death.

3. Having slept tolerably well last night, I felt so well in the morning, that I thought myself entirely recovered— At about ten this morning, the Doctor called, and observing that this was my bad day advised me to keep my bed; but I told him, I believed the affair was quite over, and I should get up in the course of an hour.— He said he wished I might not find myself mistaken, and recommended to me, at least not to rise untill noon— My impatience however could not wait quite so long— I rose at about eleven, but had not been five minutes up before I found myself so weak and faint that I was obliged to lye down again to recover myself— I did not however return to bed, but walked about my chamber and sat upon the Sopha untill about 6 in the Evening, with no small fever upon me all the time— I had sent several times to see the Doctor, who was not at home— He came at about 7. in the Evening, while I was in the height of my fever, but observed that there was nothing now to be done, as the disease must take its natural course.— I had nothing to do but to lye quiet, and drink limonade.— For about three hours I continued in the heat of a furnace, with every pulse in my body beating as if they would burst through,
and at about 11. at night the fever went off, with a perspiration such as I never before experienced. Every pore in me, seemed turned into a fountain, and all the linen around me, was as if it had been dragged through a river.— I then changed it and passed the night in my wife’s bed— She got what rest she could upon mine— The violent perspiration was followed by another effect which obliged me to rise.

4. I continued in a cool and mild perspiration through the whole night, which prevented me from sleeping at all.— This morning, the Doctor gave me an emetic, the regular operation of which was scarcely any thing, though In a different course it was very considerable— Slept

5. My fever fit came on this morning at about 8. I kept my bed the whole day, drinking limonade, and taking every two hours a powder consisting chiefly of Sal-Ammoniac.— At about 2. afternoon the perspiration came on, and continued untill 8 in the Evening.— It was very profuse almost the whole time; yet neither that nor the violence of the fever, was in any degree comparable to the severity of the last fit.— The effect which followed that, took place, in the midst of this and was extremely troublesome.— At 8 in the Evening, I rose for about half an hour, but found myself excessively weak, and soon returned to a refreshed chamber, and a dry bed.

6. Had an indifferent night, and not much sleep.— Took another emetic this morning, which was rather more successful than the last, and brought off, a very little bile— Its other operation was much more considerable.

7. My fever fit came on this morning at about 7, and was entirely over by 1. in the afternoon— It was very slight indeed, and not to be compared with any of the former ones; at about 2. I rose, and began taking a preparation of lenitive electuary, bark, and salts; two tea-spoon-fulls every two hours; the object of which is to remove the fever.

8. Had a very good night’s rest, and continued to take my medecine all day, from 6 in the morning untill 10. at night— It has the same operation as all the other medecines I have taken during my illness.

9. A tolerable night— Continued the medecine all this day— It was the fever day— I had not a regular fit; but during several hours had from time to time transient feverish flushes in the face, hands, and feet; with dull pains in all my limbs, and slight perspirations— In the evening I was much better.

10. Received letters from Berlin; and from Mr: Murray.— Wrote a few lines to Mr: Welsh; find I write with difficulty— Took a short walk in the Prince’s garden before dinner, which fatigued me considerably.

11. This was regularly the fever day; but I did not perceive the smallest trace of it; but was on the contrary better, than I have been before since I was first taken ill— Walked before dinner, and again towards evening; the weather extremely warm.
12. After an excessive hot morning, we had several thunder showers— Walked in the Garden towards Evening.— I begin to be able to read a little again; and have resumed Wieland’s Agathon.

13. It rained almost the whole day through; so that I could not venture to walk out— Wrote, the greatest part of the forenoon— Letter to Mr: Murray.— Read likewise; part of the second volume of Agathon, which is rather tedious.— The style of Wieland is far less entertaining than that of Lessing.— He is very diffuse, and as appears to me, very superficial.
14. Walked both before and after dinner— Went to the play in the Evening— Saw the fair maid of the mill; an Opera— The Music by Paisiello— Mrs: Adams began to drink the Pyrmont waters.

15. Was not so well as I have been for some days past; wrote a short letter to Mr: King. Walked before dinner, and towards Evening; alone, and with Mrs: Adams— Met Count Panin, walking.— I am apprehensive that Mrs: Adams will derive no benefit from the waters and baths here— Hitherto they seem to have done her more harm than good.

16. Wrote to my brother Thomas. Walked two or three times in the course of the day— Count Brühl called to see us, this afternoon— He has just arrived from Carlsbad.— Continue to read Wieland’s Agathon.

17. Received letters from Berlin &c— Wrote to the Secretary of State— Walk after dinner. Went to the play, in the Evening, and saw Kotzebue’s Sonnenjungfrau, or Virgin of the Sun. The performance was indifferent.— The last scene is too long; and the part of Rolla, is an “hors d’oeuvre”.

18: Took a walk this morning to the Schlossberg, an high hill about 2 miles distant, with the ruins of an old castle upon it, which belonged to the famous Wallenstein— The prospect from it is very extensive, and beautiful; and somewhat resembles that from the Mont Calvaire near Paris.— After dinner, resumed our usual Sunday’s employment, which owing to my sickness has been omitted the two last weeks— Went to the tea-party, which was given by Countess Golowkin— To the play where we saw Kotzebue’s, death of Rolla, a sequel to the Sonnenjungfrau, and the original of Sheridan’s new play entitled Pizarro— After the play, we went for about an hour to the ball— Count & Countess Panin were there— They do not return to Berlin, as all diplomatic intercourse between Russia and Prussia is to be broken off.— Saw likewise Mr: Wright.

19. Walk before dinner with Mrs: Adams in the garden. Called at Count Brühl’s lodgings in the afternoon to see him, but he was not at home— Mr: Wright paid us a visit— Walked with Mrs: Adams, almost to the foot of the Schlossberg— It was too far for her, and she was extremely fatigued, upon our return.

20. Letter from Berlin; and wrote to Mr: Murray— Walked to the house upon the hill opposite to the great alley of the Prince’s garden.— Saw Count Golowkin in the Garden as I returned. Evening at the play— Saw Axur, an Opera, translated from Beaumarchais’s Tarare. The music by Salieri— The story is taken from the tales of the Genii.— Have finished Wieland’s Agathon, and am reading his Goldne Spiegel.

21. Rained very hard all the forenoon— Took a short walk after dinner. Evening at the play, which was for the benefit of the whole company. The performance was Die Jagd, or the chase—an Opera; taken from the french partie de chasse d’Henri 4, or from the English—king, & Miller of Mansfield— The music was very indifferent— Sat next to Mr: Hildebrand, a gentleman belonging to Prague.
22. Walk before dinner— At the tea party given by Countess Reuss— At the play. “The Servant of two Masters,” a Comedy, with some low humour, but on the whole very indifferent— Written by Schröder—

23. Wrote in the forenoon— At the tea-party after dinner, given by the Countess de Llano. Saw there Count Caraman, who goes to-morrow, for Berlin— Spent the Evening at home, and read an Act of Shakespear’s Richard 3. to Mrs: Adams— Visit with her in the afternoon, to the Countess de Werthern.

24. Writing all the morning to Mr: Murray— Walked after dinner to the Schlossberg.— At the Princess of Coburg’s tea-party— Took tea— Mrs: A. went with Miss Hildprand to take a ride, but they were obliged by the rain immediately to return.— Was at the play, and saw a translation of the Busy Body, by Jünger— The play is very much shortened from the English original.

25. Had a very bad night, and have some apprehensions of my fever’s returning— I waked at two in the morning, and could not afterwards sleep again.— Had no complaint however through the day— The doctor called, and advised me to resume the use of his mixed bark and electuary.— Took a walk, completely round the town— It rained almost all last night, and part of the morning— This afternoon the weather was very cold— Went to the play, which was a translation of Richard Coeur de Lion. Finished Wieland’s Goldne Spiegel, and began to read his Danischmend.— I likewise for some mornings past have generally read a book, or half a book of his Oberon.

26. An indifferent night again, though better than the last. Walked before dinner alone, and in the afternoon, with Mrs: Adams— Count Brühl, called to see us. In the Evening at the play— Saw the Lorbeerkranz, or laurel crown, by Ziegler, a good comedy.

27. Letter from Mr: Welsh, by the Post— Wrote to him.— Walked before dinner to the foot of the Schlossberg. Went in the afternoon to Kloster Ossegg, a monastery about 6 miles distant from Töplitz— We were in company with a Baron Hildprand, his lady, son, and daughter; a family belonging to Prague who lodge next door to us, and who have been uncommonly civil to us. Being well acquainted with the prior of the Monastery, they introduced us to him, and he shewed us all his apartments and the garden in which however we found nothing very remarkable— The situation and prospect are very fine. The convent is of the Cistercian order, and was founded in the year 1196. The number of the monks is twenty; besides the various officers of the institution, who amount to about twenty more— The revenues of the prior are about 80,000 florins, or near 8000 pounds Sterling a year. Those of the monks are comparatively very small— We were told, not more than three or four hundred florins a year, for each one. In the apartments of the prior, which are large and numerous, we saw some indifferent portraits, and several old maps hung up— A small cabinet of minerals not much in order, and of which the prior told us, he understood nothing—a barometer—an harpsichord, and several volumes of music, particularly Mozart’s works; but no library.— The prior played us an air upon the harpsichord, and performed very well— He is apparently a man of about fifty; tall and strong built, but not large; his hair is just beginning to turn from black to grey. His countenance is open and placid, his manners obliging, but without the polish, which is acquired only by frequent intercourse with the world— He has held his present station only a few months, and had been before, one of the ordinary monks of the convent, with an income of two or three hundred florins. In the garden, were various
Cascades, and fountains, a pond, containing a number of small black turtles, with a small island in the centre, on the top of which was a small model of a fort, which they call the turtle’s fortress: and another pond with a similar island in the centre, upon which were kept a number of rabbits— Several small huts built of bark, and covered with thatch, containing sofa’s, and turkish, resting beds; and two sets of machines, for different sports requiring gentle exercise.— Some of the water works were disposed so as to be suddenly played off, and caught us in an unexpected shower— We had tea, with various kinds of fruit in a summer house, at the bottom of the garden, from which we had a beautiful prospect over all the plains, to the stupendous rock of Billin, and the Millischauer mountain, one of the highest in Bohemia— Between 6 and 7. o’clock we took our leave, and came through the church which is large, and handsome, with some fine paintings in fresco upon the cieling— We reached Töpliz again at about eight in the Evening.

28— Baron Hildprandt lent me one of his horses this morning, and I rode with him and Baron Macneven OKelly to the ruins of the Castle upon the Geyersberg, which we passed, on the road from Dresden. We dismounted, and with some difficulty reached the spot upon which the Castle itself was built— It must have been long in ruins; for within the walls, on a spot where one of the apartments must have been, we saw the trunk of a tree, at least 12 inches in diameter; which has very recently been cut down. The prospect is uncommonly beautiful— It was almost 2 afternoon when we returned to Töplitz.— We had only time to dine, and at 4. set out, with Baron Hildprandt, his son and daughter, and a young emigrant from Brussels, by the name of Dumont, and went to Dux, the seat of Count Wallenstein. Mrs: Adams, went with Miss Hildprandt, in a chaise—the rest of us, on a carriage of peculiar construction, such as I have seen no where else but here— It is merely a long bench covered with cushion, upon which the riders sit astride, one before the other; placed upon a floor suspended upon springs, and running upon four low wheels— Being very low, it is well adapted for safety in roads like those of this country, and being perfectly open on all sides can intercept no part of the charming prospects which are continually presenting themselves to the view.— Dux is nearly at the same distance from Töplitz as Ossegg, and the road to it is for the greatest part of the way, the same. Count Wallenstein, to whom Baron Hildprandt introduced us, shewed us his stables, in which he has nearly an hundred horses; some of them very good ones.— All his occupation, and all his amusement is, attending to these horses; of which he carries on a trade.— He made two of them perform some tricks, such as lying down, sitting upon their hind legs &c, which they executed very indifferently.— We walked in the garden of the castle, which is spacious, and might easily be made handsome, but is kept in very indifferent order— We did not see the inside of the castle— Between 6 and 7. we returned to Teplitz.

29. Very much fatigued after my two rides of yesterday. Took a walk however before dinner, and found, at length the garden of Dorn.— Count Brühl called upon us this afternoon, to invite us on the part of Madame de Krüdener to a tea-party at Dopperlburg; but we could not conveniently go— Went to the play in the Evening; saw Die Zauberflöte, or the enchanted flute, an Opera— The music composed by Mozart. Very long; and being indifferently performed, somewhat tedious.— The Opera itself is taken probably from some fairy tale.

30. Walked again, before dinner to the garden at Dorn, and partly over the garden itself; and in the afternoon, upon the range of hills upon which the Berg schenk, or tavern opposite the great hill of the Prince’s garden stands— The prospects are beautiful, and varied from any that I have seen before. Saw the village of Geraderup, the seat of Custenblatt, and another ruined castle on a summit towards the Millischauer’s berg— Finished Wieland’s Danischmend, which contrary to the usual course of books, becomes more entertaining, as it draws towards the end— Began Forster’s views upon the lower Rhine &c.

31. Letters from America, from Mr: Murray, and from Berlin— Wrote in the forenoon. Short walk in the garden before dinner.— In the afternoon, again to the same hill where I went yesterday, but by a different road— Baron Hildprandt, his Lady and daughter called and took leave of us— They go to-morrow morning— We have found them a very amiable, and uncommonly obliging family— Were at Countess Golowkin’s tea-party, which was small; the company having very much thinned away.— Played Boston, with the Countess, the Chevalier de Villenotte andMrs: Adams being unwell, did not go out. Since the 25th: she bathes at the Steinbad, out of town.

Day. The first ten days of this month I was ill, and confined to the house; part of the time, even to my bed. since then, I have usually risen at about 7.— Read half an hour, and walked in the chamber as much: breakfasted between 8 and 9. Read again untill noon— Walk an hour— Dine— Read after dinner till 4. Walk an hour— At the tea-party, and afterwards at the play. Bed before ten— Spent a few evenings at home— Have written very little this month.
